generated_text: The structure of ice II, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has been the subject of intense research for decades. However, the structure of the hydrate phase, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure, has not been resolved. Here, we report the structure of the hydrate phase of water at high pressure and temperature. We demonstrate that neon atoms can be enclathrated in water molecules to form ice II-structured hydrates. This finding has implications for the structure of the hydrate phase, which is the most stable phase of water at high pressure and temperature. It also has implications for the structure of the liquid phase, which is the most stable phase of water at low pressure.

We provide a purely categorical definition of quantum theory. The definition is based on a small number of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are similar to those of classical mechanics and classical field theory. The definition of quantum theory is thus a natural generalization of these theories. The axioms are inspired by the reconstruction programs of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are of great interest to biologists because of their extreme reduction in body plan and gene content. Here, we present a comparison of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. We also show that the myxozoan genome is highly reduced in gene content, and we identify candidate genes that are missing in the myxozoan lineage. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content.

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to block the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is responsible for this activity and that it does so by directly interacting with the Nup98-Rae1 complex, which is essential for the nuclear import of ISGs. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 is not completely understood. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Climate change will affect global food production, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to project the future variability of maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the variability of maize yields will increase everywhere. This increase in variability will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year in the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species differ in their diets is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that the degree of diet overlap between species was correlated with the degree of overlap in the proportion of plant species consumed. This suggests that the degree of diet overlap between species may be a useful indicator of competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages. Our results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have implications for the management of large herbivore populations.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important and most debated questions in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 presolar grains that formed in the interstellar medium. We found that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We also found that the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has increased by a factor of 10. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to produce offspring is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to produce offspring is also one of the most important traits in domestication and all forms of allocare. We find that domestication and allocare increase reproductive output, and that the increase is due to an increase in the energy available to the mother.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system, the basal ganglia, and the cerebral cortex. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the central nervous system. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to reduce the load of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to limit the neurodegenerative process in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising drug for the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is the first cell to come into contact with circulating blood and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is also the first cell to respond to injury and infection and is the primary cell type responsible for inflammation and coagulation. The endothelium is a highly specialized cell type that is able to control its own function and that of other cells in the body. This paper describes the nature of the communication system that operates between endothelial cells. The communication system is highly effective in controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, and in controlling inflammation and coagulation. The communication system is also effective in controlling the contractility of blood vessels, which is essential for controlling blood pressure.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges, especially for public health researchers and policymakers. We present the COVIDcast API, a data platform that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 signals, including traditional public health surveillance data and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The COVIDcast API is intended to empower researchers and policymakers with the data they need to understand and respond to the pandemic.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and, therefore, are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel’s pore and is the site of ion conduction. The selectivity filter is also the site of the activation gate, which is the gate that opens the channel’s pore to the outside. We have identified a key residue that is functionally and structurally coupled to the activation gate. We have shown that this residue is crucial for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex community of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and other microorganisms that play important roles in the health of the animal and the ecosystem. The role of fungi in the gut microbiome is less well understood, but they are known to be important in the digestive process. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a key feature of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We identify a key role for the brain nucleus accumbens in the development of social rank, and show that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate due to reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, which enhances brain energy metabolism, prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The ability to program mechanical responses of materials and structures is of great importance for the development of functional devices. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures, which seamlessly collaborate to produce the target responses. The structures are digitally synthesized with irregular distributions of material phases, which are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a key example of a developmental program that is regulated by the circadian clock. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway that regulates the expression of hemoglobin in humans. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 is down-regulated in fetal tissues and up-regulated in adult tissues. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 mediates the loss of fetal hemoglobin expression and the gain of adult hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Ferroptosis is a form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. We also found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis contributes to ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Finally, we demonstrated that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a therapeutic target for cancer treatment in patients with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) through a mechanism that involves the activation of the STIM/ORAI Ca2+ sensor complex. Our findings suggest that the use of LCCBs should be carefully considered in patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, but the policy failed to reverse the decline of these populations on private lands, where clearcutting continued. The NWFP’s success in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations is explained by the policy’s focus on older forests and the fact that the policy was implemented on federal land. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, since the evolution of pathogens is fast and efficient. We present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. We show that the design strategy is effective, since the best compounds designed by us are up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, against resistant pathogens. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics against other antibiotic-resistant pathogens. (Show more)

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and consists of a single set of operations. This architecture is easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The evolution of Lake Malawi, East Africa, is a key example of how the transport of moisture in the tropics has influenced the landscape, migration pathways, and evolution of life on Earth. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of the region, which shows that the lake has been far more dynamic in the past than previously thought. The shift in hydroclimate at the MPT, around 800,000 years ago, is consistent with far-field climate forcing and is associated with a change in the orbital forcing of the climate system. We show that the lake was much lower before the MPT, and that the lake level was higher and more variable during the last glacial period.

The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the effects of these devices on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces the following night’s sleep. These effects are likely to have important implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Ytterby meteorite, which fell in Sweden in 1911, contains 187Os/188Os ratios of 0.13, similar to the average of the solar system. This suggests that the solar system has a reservoir of osmium (Os) with a high 187Os/188Os ratio. We show that the YDB Os in bulk samples and magnetic grains/microspherules from Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio have 187Os/188Os ratios ≥1.0, similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. The YDB site in Pennsylvania is remarkable in yielding 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules containing minerals such as suessite (Fe-Ni silicide) that form at temperatures in excess of 2000 °C. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 expression in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmunity, which is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is not only restricted to the early stages of T cell activation.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles, revealing that the origin of Coleoptera occurred in the Carboniferous, and that plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles. These novel genes triggered adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles, which resulted in nearly half of all living beetle species.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to efficiently enhance antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

We report the results of a large-scale experiment that investigates the role of population size in the evolution of technology. We find that larger populations do not enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of technology. This finding is important because it suggests that the size of the population is not the only factor that determines the rate of evolution of a population.

The strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is protective whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. APOE is also highly associated with astrocytes, a major cell type in the central nervous system that is highly phagocytic. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles are highly associated with the accumulation of a complement component in senescent synapses, which may contribute to the increased vulnerability of these synapses to complement-mediated neurodegeneration. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,200 km in diameter and 1,200 km in height. It is the densest part of the Earth, and it is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the planet. The inner core is a paradox because it is formed by a process that is not thermodynamically possible. This study provides a solution to the paradox, which is that the inner core is formed by a two-step process. In the first step, the molten iron cools below the melting point. In the second step, the iron crystallizes into the stable, hexagonal, close-packed phase.

Marijuana is the most widely used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are key features of marijuana abuse.

Language is the defining cognitive skill of the human brain. Yet, despite its importance, we lack a mechanistic understanding of how the human brain processes language. Here, we show that deep learning models that have been trained on unrelated tasks can predict brain responses to sentences in the human brain. This suggests that the brain’s language processing mechanisms are tuned to predict the next word in a sentence. We also find that the predictive power of models is correlated with their accuracy on a language task. These results provide computational guidance for how to design future studies of language comprehension in the brain. They also have implications for the design of artificial intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that we do not know how to train stable neural networks. We introduce a new algorithm, which we prove is stable and numerically verifies that it is fast. Moreover, we prove that only a small number of layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including the failure of governments to act quickly enough, the spread of misinformation, and the inability of people to understand exponential growth. This paper shows that the latter factor is not only a major contributing factor but also the result of a flawed experiment. The experiment, which is often cited as evidence for the inability of people to understand exponential growth, is itself flawed.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years, and it is still a major public health problem in many parts of the world. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the pathogenicity of the uncultured Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the majority of cases of leprosy, has only recently been investigated. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably conserved, and that they are closer to each other than to the MRCA of all other mycobacteria. This suggests that they have retained many of the functions required to cause disease for a long time.

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the laws of thermodynamics, respectively. Therefore, understanding their interplay is of utmost importance. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in a quantum system can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit, which is a regime that is not accessible to experiments.

The development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is of utmost importance to combat the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain. This vaccine candidate is easy to manufacture, has a large-scale production potential, and is highly protective in a relevant animal model.

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, was one of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that of human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice. Here, we present a mathematical model that describes the spread of plague by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work has implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its impact on human societies.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain power, which is the number of neurons, is even more important because it is the ultimate measure of the computational capacity of the brain. This study shows that the evolution of brain power is different from that of brain size. The evolution of brain power is not only different between endotherms and ectotherms but also between birds and mammals. This has important implications for the study of the evolution of animal cognition.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have found that TRAP1 is expressed at low levels in normal tissues and at higher levels in transformed cells, and that TRAP1 is required for the transformation of mouse fibroblasts. We have also found that TRAP1 promotes the metabolic switch from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis, and that this metabolic switch is required for the transformation of mouse fibroblasts. These data suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate many cellular processes. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled, and this process is regulated by proteins that bind and unbind the filaments. One of these proteins, cofilin, is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that cofilin binds to the filaments and, upon binding, it induces a mechanical torque that enhances severing. This mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks, which is essential for many cellular processes. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is a general feature of filament severing.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is associated with increased body weight and obesity. This study provides evidence that fructose may also be a stronger appetite suppressant and food-seeking stimulus than glucose. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of action of sweeteners and may help explain the popularity of fructose-sweetened beverages.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. It is the only island in the world where the Austronesian language family is spoken, and it is the only place where the Bantu language family is spoken. We present a detailed picture of the human history of Madagascar, which is a key step in understanding the origin and the spread of these two language families.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when those others are thousands of miles away. This is a major finding, because it suggests that people are not immune to the influence of the emotions of others, and that this influence can be positive. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but only recently has it been appreciated that these modifications can have a profound impact on the translation of the mRNA. We show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in the mRNA can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can have a significant impact on the translation of the mRNA. This work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in the translation of mRNAs. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. This finding suggests that the sense of meaningfulness in life may be a key factor in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life course.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of life in water. We use a model of the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation to show that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is consistent with the evolution of a smaller minimum size and a maximum size constrained by the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation, respectively.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold, and the ability of the virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature is a key factor in the pathogenesis of the common cold. We show that this temperature-dependent growth phenotype is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment, and the mechanisms they use to respond to environmental signals are critical for their survival. Here we show that the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its surface-adhesion system to sense surfaces. This mechanism is used to promote long-term attachment to surfaces, which is critical for the pathogen’s ability to survive and cause disease.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a substantial risk for the biological integrity of global water resources. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple human lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that are needed to move toward sustainable hydropower. We find that the main causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world are the lack of alternatives, the lack of consideration of climate change, and the lack of consideration of the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau protein in the brain. Although the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is well established, the contribution of other components of the amyloid cascade hypothesis, such as the neurotoxic oligomeric Aβ species, is less clear. Here, we show that oligomeric Aβ is not required for the initiation of an inflammatory response in the brain, since neighboring glial cells also produce a variety of immune factors. However, we demonstrate that the intraneuronal accumulation of oligomeric Aβ is a significant contributor to the neuroinflammatory response, since neighboring glial cells do not express similar molecules. Thus, we identify the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a better understanding of the complex interplay between the brain’s immune system and the neurodegenerative process, and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. It is a main source of protein for more than one billion people worldwide. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Hellenistic period. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that has been studied extensively because of its large size and because it folds through a distinct native-like intermediate. We find that the intermediate is an obligatory step on the folding pathway and that the protein folds in more than one step. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. However, the precise role of Np4 in the stress response remains unclear. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping Np4-capped transcripts, which it does by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. This unique manner of substrate recognition positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The differential impact of RppH on the rates at which capped and noncapped 5′ termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, it is also responsible for the development of the immunosuppression that is a major cause of the disease’s severity. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid that can be synthesized from arginine, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the planet. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and wild mammals, and the need for a more complete view of the biomass of the biosphere.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a system, which is initially in a quiet state, suddenly becomes active, and then the activity decays to the initial state in a power-law fashion. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, such as sandpiles, neural networks, and fracture processes. In this paper, we report on the discovery of a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. Here, we show that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond. We demonstrate that strain can be used to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense of plants against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the antifungal activity of plant immune peptides against plant fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes, and it is likely to be a site of molecular continuity. However, the extent of such continuity is largely unknown. We used proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract makes a substantial contribution to the sperm proteome, and we identify a number of female-derived proteins that are likely to support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a critical component of the blood clotting system. Mutations in VWF cause the common human bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD mutations, which are known to increase the effects of mutations. The results also suggest that the force-switchable state of the receptor−ligand complex may be a general feature of biomolecular systems.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that is intimately linked to human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, in part because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, which can be used to study the role of viruses in human disease. The database is freely available to the scientific community, and can be used to study the human virome in a wide range of contexts.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes, such as the influence of aerosols on water cloud droplet formation. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, was used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a central issue in the study of the history of life. Here we present a method for inferring the temperature of Earth’s surface in the past based on the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. This method provides a new approach to the study of the history of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the main ion-conducting proteins in cells and are important for the normal function of the nervous system and heart. Ion channels are also involved in a variety of diseases, including epilepsy, cardiac arrhythmia, and diabetes. Ion channels are composed of a large number of protein subunits, and the structure and function of each subunit are different. In this study, we found that the potassium channel BK has a unique feature that its activation and inactivation gates are spatially overlapped.

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide and is a major cause of death in sub-Saharan Africa. The Plasmodium parasite uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell, the target of the disease. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) binds to glycophorin A (GPA) on the red cell surface and alters the biophysical properties of the cell. We show that the reduction in the bending modulus of the cell membrane is correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is brittle and difficult to process. Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, and its bandgap can be reduced to zero, by applying strain. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and energy storage.

The impact of ambient humidity on the severity of influenza virus infection is of great interest to public health. In this study, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s response to words varies with each successive word in a sentence but suddenly when words can be merged into phrases. This response is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases.

Wnt signaling is a key pathway in development, and the two vertebrate Axin proteins are genetically redundant. We show that the two proteins are regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that the two forms of Axin are differentially responsive to Wnt signaling. This differential responsiveness may be used to control the pathway in different tissues.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which in turn inhibit dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons, the VTA, or the dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that LH neurons, via the VTA, inhibit dopamine neurons, which in turn inhibit feeding. This circuit may contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-bacterial symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signal for the control of bacterial gene expression in association with the plant.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their ears to listen to the world around them. The ears of animals are diverse, and the auditory organs of all animals are part of the body. Here, we show that the ears of the orb-weaving spider are not constrained by the organism’s body, and we demonstrate that the spider’s ears are outsourced to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is much more sensitive to sound than the spider’s body. The spider can also regenerate its web, which allows it to adjust the sensitivity of its ears to its needs. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing, the design of acoustic sensors, and the regeneration of sensory organs.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has affected the lives of billions of people worldwide. Vaccines are the most effective way to control the pandemic, but the current vaccines are not available to all the people who need them. We report a strategy to make a subunit vaccine that is easy to manufacture and can be used to make billions of doses annually. This strategy can be used to make vaccines for other diseases as well.

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand system in the development of neural crest-derived tissues is unknown. Here, we show that the zebrafish ALK/ALKALS are involved in the development of iridophores, a pigment cell type of neural crest origin. We provide evidence that the three zebrafish ALK/ALKALS are able to activate the human ALK/ALKALS in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK/ALKALS in neural crest development and suggest that the ALK/ALKALS are potential therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis, the cause of the Black Death, is one of the most dramatic events in human history. We present a large dataset of Y. pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which is the earliest time period for which we have a sufficient number of genomes to explore its diversity. We find that Y. pestis was not a single lineage but rather a single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of Y. pestis in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of Y. pestis. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Less)

This work examines the role of the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support.

The management of agricultural lands has a profound impact on the global carbon cycle. In the United States, the conversion of grasslands to crop production has led to the release of massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that the adoption of soil health management practices, such as reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations, and the use of manure, can mitigate this trend. These practices increase the storage of carbon in the soil, which is a key component of climate mitigation strategies. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to contribute to climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to systematically identify the most likely zoonotic viruses that have not yet emerged. We hope that this work will inform the development of strategies to reduce the risk of spillover and the subsequent emergence of new viruses.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for the services they provide in the form of pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce colored nectar are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify this compound in the nectar of hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae, providing evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a widespread and convergently evolved trait that is likely to be favored by natural selection.

We present a case study of the genetic legacy of a population movement that occurred during the Early Middle Ages. We show that the genetic ancestry of the individuals in our sample is consistent with the movement of people from southeastern Europe to central Europe. In addition, we find that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study demonstrates that genome-wide data can provide insights into the complex processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe human pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and its potential to cause future pandemics.

The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical for the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging pathogens. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We found that vector-borne pathogens were the most common cause of undifferentiated febrile illness, but that underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV, were also detected. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using metagenomic next-generation sequencing to identify the pathogens responsible for undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. Ongoing pathogen surveillance using metagenomics can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be used to identify pathogens in other settings, including resource-rich settings. (Show more)

DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of pol δ and its role in lagging strand synthesis. These findings also have implications for the design of therapeutic agents that target pol δ. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate RNA, but the process is inefficient. Here, we report the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA with high efficiency. This polymerase ribozyme can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Thus, the polymerase ribozyme can now be used to reconstruct the two prerequisites of life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—in the complete absence of proteins.

We use computer vision to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods over time. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the physical environment in shaping the economic fortunes of neighborhoods.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the process of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can improve the clinical outcome of severe and critical COVID-19 patients immediately. Therefore, tocilizumab is a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess is toxic to most organisms. The ability of fungi to regulate copper is poorly understood, but is likely to be important for their interactions with other microbes. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with other microbes.

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a key mineral for understanding the conditions of its formation. Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of this mineral in a sedimentary rock in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the crater. The presence of other cogenetic detrital phases, such as feldspar, cristobalite, and magnetite, is also consistent with silicic volcanism. The presence of amorphous precipitated silica, and possibly the crystalline magnetite, is consistent with the presence of acidic aqueous fluids.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that the resistance strategies of trees are not well adapted to the new frost regimes. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management, forestry, and agriculture to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the contribution of Th17 cells to the pathogenesis of these diseases is unclear. We found that Th17 cells, which express both IL-17A and IFN-γ, are required for the development of colitis in a Th17 transfer model. Th17 cells were required for the development of both IL-17A+ and IL-17F+ cells, but only the latter were required for the development of colitis. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the only cells in the human body that cannot be replaced. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, which can be used to study the disease and screen for therapeutics. This method will enable the study of the disease in large numbers and will be a powerful tool for ALS research.

The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the host microbiota is a key factor in the success of many human and animal pathogens. Here, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which causes human granulocytic anaplasmosis, is able to alter the composition of the tick microbiota, which in turn influences the ability of the bacterium to colonize the tick. We demonstrate that the bacterium induces the tick to produce antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the structure of the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, which is a critical obstacle for the colonization of the bacterium in the gut. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transformations in the history of life. The study of the origin and early evolution of the avian tail is a key to understanding the origin of the modern body plan. Here, we describe a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, which are often used to avoid detection by predators. In some cases, animals have evolved to be invisible to the human eye, which is why they are difficult to see in nature. We show that some animals are invisible to the human eye because of their color, which is not visible to the human eye.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are thought to be responsible for the initiation and maintenance of the disease. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces the expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. We also show that ALKBH5 overexpression decreases NANOG mRNA methylation, increases NANOG levels, and increases the percentage of BCSCs, phenocopying the effect of hypoxia. Thus, ALKBH5 mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world, and the first pocket Bible was a significant innovation in the history of books. The source of the parchment used to make these early pocket Bibles has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we present a method to determine the animal origin of parchment, which can be used to settle this controversy.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the event. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the ecosystem was not fully recovered for ∼500 ka. These results will improve our understanding of the causes and consequences of the extinction. (Less)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the external environment. It is essential to maintain the homeostasis of the intestinal epithelium to prevent the invasion of pathogens and the release of harmful substances. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the first line of the immune system, and it is necessary to maintain the balance between the immune response and the inflammatory response. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic strategy for the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for vaccine development and the focus of many studies on the mechanisms of viral entry. We use cryo-electron microscopy to determine the structure of the spike protein in complex with the receptor, ACE2, and a lipid bilayer. We find that the spike protein adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanisms of viral entry and may inform the design of vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibrium in repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. In this setting, the payoff of each player depends only on what happens in the long run, and not on the particular history of the game. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has resulted in a 1.13-y reduction in life expectancy at birth and a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y for the total US population. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry, and they are the key to understanding the properties of matter. In this paper, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms, and that these changes can be predicted by a simple model.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate change and human demography on fire activity and carbon emissions, and we show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results suggest that recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse the warming trend of the last century, potentially reducing global warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, but with some risk of more extreme fires regionally and with implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which animals regulate the activities of their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. We demonstrate that the glycan is provided to the squid only at night, when the symbiotic organ is at its most active, and that its catabolism is required for the acidification of the organ that enhances the activity of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis, and suggests that the provision of nutrients to specific microbes may be a more common mechanism for the maintenance of tissue health than previously thought. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to identify latent topics in a large corpus of violent death narratives from the US National Violent Death Reporting System. We find that the topics are gendered, and that the gender bias of the topics matches the gender bias of the underlying data. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains, and can be extended to other types of data. We believe that it will be useful to researchers and practitioners in many fields.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, was introduced into Europe in the 14th century. This event marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that these conditions were also favorable for the survival of the bacterium in the Asian reservoirs that were reintroduced into Europe. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y.

Asteroids are a group of marine invertebrates that are of great interest to the scientific community and the public. In the last 2 y, a disease has been observed in populations of asteroids along the Pacific coast of North America. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is associated with rapid mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, which allowed us to study the distribution of the African and Asian ancestry in a fine-grained way. We find that the population of Madagascar is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is also complex, with a recent population growth and a sex-biased colonization. Finally, we find that the distribution of the African and Asian ancestry is not only a consequence of the admixture, but also of the demographic history of Madagascar.

Bacteria are able to respond to a variety of stresses by altering the expression of their genes. One way that bacteria can respond to stress is by altering the expression of small RNAs. These small RNAs are able to regulate the expression of other genes, and can be used to regulate the expression of other small RNAs. Here we describe one such small RNA that is able to regulate the expression of two other small RNAs.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains a major obstacle to the development of antiviral and vaccine strategies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the immune system’s ability to recognize and neutralize SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules.
